title: Belgian Great War unknown soldier finally laid to rest
first_lines: Tuesday 11 November is Armistice Day, the day on which we commemorate the end of the First World War. On Monday, the eve of Armistice Day, a double memorial service was held in the West Flemish municipalities of Diksmuide and De Panne for a Belgian unknown soldier that died during the First World War. The soldier’s remains were found during construction work near to the banks of the River IJzer at Diksmuide. Following a torchlight procession along the banks of the IJzer and a commemoration ceremony, the soldier’s remains were buried with full military honours at the Belgian military cemetery in De Panne.
content: It is very rare that the remains of Belgian First World War soldiers are found. The previous time this happened prior to the latest discovery was in 2016. The soldier was reburied in 2018. Prior to that we would have to go back to 1952. Although the remains of soldiers that fell during the First World War are often found in the Westhoek area of West Flanders, most of them are British, German or French.

Last September construction workers discovered human remains while they were working on a new cycle path on the IJzer Dyke in Diksmuide. The discovery came just a couple of hundred metres from the history Dodengang (Corridor of Death) trench complex that formed the Belgian Army’s front on the River IJzer during the First World War. The remains were examined by the Flemish Immovable Heritage Agency and the War Heritage Institute. They soon concluded that the remains were those of a Belgian WWI soldier.

Items found with the soldier’s remains, including a uniform button with the Belgian lion on it, a rudimentary ring with the inscription 1915 and a post horn, confirmed his that he was Belgian. However, DNA tests were unable to establish his identity. He has therefore been buried as “unknown”.
On Monday afternoon the soldier was buried with full military honnours at the De Panne Military cemetery. This is the largest Belgian Great War cemetery in the country.

Among those present were Belgium’s Head of State King Filip, Defence Ministry representatives and the Mayor of Dikmuide Koen Coupillie (nationalist) and the Mayor of Wim Janssens De Panne (liberal). They were joined by around 200 members of the public.

The War Heritage Institute stresses that Monday’s exceptional event underlines the importance of remembrance education. “Remembrance is important. We must never forget this. We reflect on the sacrifices, but also on the misery that the war brought,” the War Heritage Institute’s Steve Maertens said.

title: National Bank warns of “worrying outlook” for public debt
first_lines: Once again, the National Bank of Belgium has expressed concern about the state of Belgium's public finances. Although France, Italy, Japan and the US have far higher debt ratios than Belgium, the National Bank warns that Belgium's debt position is as fragile as theirs.
content: Belgium’s public debt currently stands at around 104% of GDP. This compares with 113% % in France, 135% in Italy, 122% the United States and a huge 236% in Japan. The National Bank warns however that focusing solely on headline figures can obscure deeper structural weaknesses. It argues that debt sustainability depends not only on the current level of debt, but also on future borrowing needs, fiscal trends and general economic dynamics.

In Belgium's case, short-term risks remain limited. However, the National Bank of Belgium has one major concern: the government's gross financing requirement. This amounts to around 20% of GDP each year. On the hand Belgium’s positive net foreign investment position offers some resilience, as domestic savings could help to absorb any funding shocks. Belgian savers demonstrated this resilience in 2011, when they purchased bonds after foreign investors pulled back from Belgian debt.

Looking further ahead, the National Bank describes the projected increase in Belgium’s public debt as “worrying”. It cites persistent budget deficits, mounting interest costs, and expenditure related to an ageing population.

The National Bank concludes that while our economy is not facing an immediate crisis, a sudden shift in market sentiment could quickly turn liquidity pressures into solvency risks. This would turn today's slow-burning debt dynamics into tomorrow's financial emergency.

title: Former European commissioner Didier Reynders charged with money laundering
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: Didier Reynders (Francophone liberal MR), the former Belgian cabinet minister, who also served as the Belgian on the European Commission has been officially charged with money laundering, media outlets De Standaard, Le Soir, Le Vif and the Dutch investigative platform Follow The Money report. Judicial sources have confirmed the news to the VRT. Reynders is said to have been questioned by investigators on 16 October.
content: In December last year, it emerged that a judicial investigation had been opened into possible money laundering practices by the former Belgian finance, justice and foreign minister.

Reynders is alleged to have used cash to buy National Lottery scratch cards for many years in order to see the profits laundered back into his account. The matter has come to a head after the National Lottery reported suspected money laundering to the competent authorities in 2022.
The money laundering investigation also looked at the regular deposit of large sums of cash at a bank. The total amount involved suspicious transactions said to be up to 1 million euros.
Almost a year after the case came to light, Reynders has now been officially charged. Reynders's wife, former senior magistrate Bernadette Prignon, has not been charged De Standaard writes.

Didier Reynders is alleged to have bought National Lottery tickets using cash for years, for a total amount of up to 200,000 euros. He deposited the winnings into his account allowing the money to be laundered.

The investigation also looked at sums of cash that Reynders deposited into an ING account between 2008 and 2018. These were relatively small amounts but totalled 700,000 euros. Together with the amounts for scratch cards, approximately 1 million euros is involved in all.

The Brussels Public Prosecutor's Office is conducting a separate investigation into the role in this case played by Dutch bank ING. The bank only queried the deposits for a first time in 2018 and only informed the Financial Intelligence Processing Unit (CFI) in 2023. Normally, banks are required to report suspicious transactions immediately.

title: Northern Lights seen in the skies above Flanders
first_lines: On Tuesday night the Northern Lights were visible in some parts of the north of the country. It is hoped that they will be visible again tonight.
content: Social media has been awash with photography of the (pink) Northern Lights. Although most of the photos we came across were taken in the Netherlands, the Flemish weather spotter Bart Medaer was also able to photograph the Northern Lights in the north of Antwerp Province.

On Tuesday night the Northern Lights were pink in colour. The colour of the Northern Lights depends on how deep the particles charged by what is called a “solar blast” penetrate the earth’s atmosphere.

We may get another chance to see the Northern Lights late this evening or overnight. They may well be more intense than was the case last night. Christine Verbeke of Leuven University (KU Leuven) VRT News that “A new, even faster solar storm is approaching Earth. What's more, the Earth's magnetic field is still recovering from the previous storm. This means that the impact is likely to be even greater. I am hopeful that the northern lights will be more intense than last night, but of course this remains a prediction, just like the weather forecast.”
If you don't want to miss the Northern Lights, you should look north late tonight or tonight, low on the horizon and in a dark place.
There is good news from the VRT’s weatherman Bram Verbruggen as he says that “The weather will be clear tonight.”

It started with a large explosion on the sun a few days ago. The explosion sent solar storms towards Earth. Last night, the first of these storms reached our planet. The charged particles carried by the storms collide with our atmosphere and it is this that creates the Northern Lights.

Normally, the Northern Lights can only be seen in areas such as the north of Scotland, Scandinavia, etc. However, in recent years they have also been observed several times in Belgium. This comes about where there is a peak in solar storms.

Just like on Earth, there are seasons on the Sun, during which the Sun becomes more or less active. Every 11 years, activity on the Sun peaks, and that is currently in full swing. If you want to spot the Northern Lights, it is best not to wait too long, because according to space weather expert Christine Verbeke, the peak has just passed.

title: Government crisis in the offing?
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: Belgian premier Bart De Wever’s deadline of Thursday for agreement on a multi-year budget is approaching fast.  The premier has set a goal of ‘finding’ 10 billion euros either through new taxes or government cuts, but last night federal coalition partners parted ways without agreement.  Bilateral talks between the PM and deputy premiers representing each of the parties in the 5-way coalition continue Wednesday.
content: At around 9 p.m., the federal ministers parted ways without reaching an agreement.

‘The temperature of the atmosphere has dropped well below freezing,’ one source told VRT News. Several sources point to the attitude of the Francophone liberal MR, which they claim seems unwilling to reach an agreement, as the reason. The party is opposing a VAT hike and higher taxes for Belgium's wealthiest, but has now reportedly also indicated which measures it believes could raise cash. The coalition partners also took issue with a planned visit by MR leader Georges-Louis Bouchez to Unizo East Flanders on Wednesday. Bouchez also invited the press to attend his visit to the local federation for the self-employed, on the eve of the crucial budget deadline.

The MR leader's tweets, in which he clashed with N-VA chair Valerie Van Peel on social media, did not help the atmosphere either. In a video posted on social media, Van Peel had called it ‘unbelievable’ that some fellow party leaders did not recognise the urgency of the situation and ‘did not dare to step out of their own shadow’.

If no deal can be reached by the deadline PM De Wever may visit King Filip to tender his resignation.  It then remains to be seen if the monarch will accept his premier’s offer or in true Belgian style will send him back to the negotiating table in the hope of still thrashing out a deal.

title: “Act responsibly and bridge your differences”, King Filip urges
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: The royal palace has issued a press release on behalf of Filip, King of Belgians, after the Belgian head of state met with prime minister Bart De Wever (Flemish nationalist) amid the deepening budget crisis.  Belgium’s 5-way federal coalition government is struggling to finalise a multi-year budget as demanded by the PM.
content: According to the statement "the prime minister informed the king that there are ongoing differences of opinion within his government about the budget, but that the coalition partners want to continue their work. The king took note of the prime minister's findings and urged all parties involved to act with responsibility and bridge their differences so that the country can as soon as possible have a clear budgetary path for the coming years".
The king is not setting any deadlines. But PM De Wever has agreed with key ministers that the budget must be finalised by the Christian feast of Christmas on 25 December, a public holiday in Belgium.

Next year’s budget needs to be approved by parliament in time.  Otherwise, key reforms won’t be able to start from the beginning of next year and Belgium will be obliged to operate using a temporary monthly budget that allocates a twelfth of this year’s spending to each month at the beginning of 2026.
Measures that will be delayed include some pension reforms and the introduction of the new capital gains tax.

title: Genk police surround and capture dog that local residents believed was a wolf
first_lines: Police in the Limburg city of Genk we called out to deal with what local residents believed was a wolf. However, the animal that was surrounded and eventually captured by officers on the Onderwijslaan in the early hours of Tuesday morning was in fact a Czechoslovakian wolfdog. Jan Loos of Welcome Wolf told VRT News that he understands why people thought that the dog was a wolf.
content: Two patrol cars went to the scene and first spotted the animal on Genk’s Westerring. They were able to follow what turned out to be a dog to the Onderwijslaan. There they surrounded the animal in front of a house and finally caught it. As they weren’t sure whether it was a wolf, they called in the assistance of Nature Rescue Centre. However, it soon became apparent that the animal was a dog.
During the whole incident, the dog remained remarkably calm and allowed himself to be led away from the road. The police were able to read the dog’s ID chip and he is now back with his owner.

Jan Loos confirms the dog that was caught by police on Monday night is an older Czechoslovakian wolfdog. “We receive these kinds of reports very often, especially in this area. Genk is a real hotspot for wolfdogs. They often roam around in the area near to the E314 motorway.”

“A Czechoslovakian wolfdog is a kind of cross between a wolf and a German shepherd. Not only do they resemble wolves, but they are also just as shy and clever, which means they often escape. The difference between them and real wolves is sometimes almost impossible to see, so we understand why people get confused. Fortunately, at Welcome Wolf we have years of experience with these animals and can therefore recognise them quickly”.

title: Belgium to beef up airspace security
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: “We have the situation under control” Belgian home and security minister Bernard Quintin (Francophone liberal) told international media after Thursday’s unscheduled meeting of Belgium’s security council.  The meeting was called after unidentified drones caused disruption at airports and military bases across Belgium in recent days.  Belgian security services blame Russia for the disruption.
content: After the meeting Quintin called for calm: “If the police want to be able to do something, there must be a clear legal framework for it. It is our job as politicians to look into that,” the minister said.

He emphasised that there is a mandatory registration system for drones and their pilots. "We do not live in a system where everyone can do whatever they want. We cannot ban all drones, because we also need them for our security.
“But I want to emphasize that you can get 10 to 20 years in prison if you fly a drone over the airport and endanger safety.”
Quintin provided reassurance: “We really do have the situation under control. The threat is there, I won't deny that, but we are certainly not completely left to our own devices.”
After the security  council meeting Belgian defence minister Francken (Flemish nationalist) announced the decision to strengthen the NASC, the National Air Security Center by 1 January.

"The NASC in Beauvechain (Walloon Brabant) will be strengthened by 1 January. This is the most important measure taken at the National security council meeting", defense minister Francken noted upon leaving the meeting.
“All security services together must obtain a global picture of the airspace,” he said. The NASC must ensure this.
The purchase of anti-drone equipment was also discussed, he said. He is now working on that dossier so that it can be presented to cabinet tomorrow.
“In the meantime, no hostile drones should be allowed on our territory or above our military bases. The mission and guidelines are clear: if possible, we will shoot them down!”

title: Federal Government wants lifetime ban on entry to Belgium for convicted terrorists and hate preachers
first_lines: At a meeting on Friday the Federal Cabinet decided that convicted terrorists and hate preachers that are residing in Belgium illegally may soon be subject to a lifetime ban on entering the country. Currently, bans on entering the country can only be imposed for a set period.
content: Speaking after Friday morning’s cabinet meeting, the Federal Asylum and Migration Minister Anneleen Van Bossuyt (Flemish nationalist) said that “The door will be permanently closed to those that radicalise or support terrorism”.

Ms Van Bossuyt cited convicted terrorists, potentially violent extremists, and hate preachers as examples of those that would be affected by the ban. In order to ensure an objective assessment of the security risk, any decision to ban an individual from the country will always be preceded by an analysis by the terror threat level assessment body OCAD, Ms Van Bossuyt added.
People banned from entering Belgium will be flagged in both the Schengen Information System and the national police database.

Meanwhile, the Asylum and Migration Minister also says that the number of undocumented migrants that were serving time in Belgians prisons but have been sent back to their countries of origin has increased in recent months. In the first 10 months of this year 1,300 were sent back. This compares to 1,035 in the same period last year.

Ms Van Bossuyt says that she intends to build on this trend by increasing the number of places available in secure asylum centres. More repatriation escorts will be taken on and more effective readmission agreements made with countries of origin.

"Anyone who commits criminal offences or poses a threat to our society must leave the country. By focusing more on returning those serving custodial sentences we are protecting our society and giving our overburdened prison system more breathing space."
Prison overcrowding has been an issue in Belgium for a number of years. Around a third of prisoners in Belgian jails are undocumented.

title: Belgian cabinet approves drone defence plan
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: The Belgian cabinet has now approved the counter-drone plan that defence minister Theo Francken (Flemish nationalist N-VA) proposed.
content: The minister made the announcement on X. Friday afternoon, the cabinet reached an agreement in principle on the drone defence plan. However, the final green light had not yet been given, as “a number of options” still had to be considered.
Francken's announcement means that approval has now been granted. ‘Counter-drone plan just approved by the cabinet,’ he writes.
The plan provides for the purchase of detection equipment and systems to shoot down drones, according to the post. ‘The safety of our airports and military domains is an absolute priority.’

title: Protest against UAE’s alleged complicity in the violence in Sudan
first_lines: Several hundred people have held a demonstration outside the Embassy of the United Arab Emirates in Brussels. They were protesting against what they see as the UAE’s complicity in the violence committed by the paramilitary group Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in Sudan. The protesters say that the United Arab Emirates supports RSF due to economic interests.
content: The Sudanese government says that the paramilitary group Rapid Support Forces is supported by Dubai. The United Arab Emirates strongly deny this. However, several international reports on the situation in Sudan state that the UAE has exported modern drones, heavy duty machine guns, artillery, mortars and munitions to paramilitaries in Sudan. They have done so in exchange for Sudanese gold that is found in the south of the country in areas controlled by RSF.
The organisers of the demonstration say that around 600 people took part. They are demanding an economic boycott against the United Arab Emirates.

One demonstrator told journalists that "The UAE is compliant in the genocide that is taking place in Sudan”. The demonstrator wished to remain anonymous due to fears for the safety of his family that is currently still in living in Sudan.

The protesters also denounced what they describe as the “hypocritical attitude” of Belgium and the European Union. According to the protesters, Belgian weapons are being supplied to RSF via the United Arab Emirates. They want Belgium and Europe to issue a clear condemnation of the violence.

"The EU must impose a total embargo on the United Arab Emirates and South Sudan” the anonymous activist and organiser of the demonstration said. “The export of all services and goods to the United Arab Emirates and Sudan must be stopped.”

The demonstrators add that the European Union must behave as a responsible player and not perpetuate “this proxy war”. The EU must “Take a stand and take responsibility. Belgium must stop all arms deliveries to countries that supply RSF.”

title: Fivefold increase in the number of average-speed cameras in Flanders since 2023
first_lines: The number of average-speed cameras on Flemish roads has risen sharply during the past 2 years. In 2023 there were 246 of the cameras in Flanders. Now there are 1,233. The figures come from the Federal Interior Minister Bernard Quantin (Francophone liberal). They highlight the Flemish regional authorities’ growing investment in traffic enforcement.
content: Belgium’s other 2 regions have far fewer average speed cameras installed alongside their roads. According to figures published in the dailies ‘Het Nieuwsblad’ and ‘Gazet van Antwerpen’, Wallonia has 97 of the cameras, while the Brussels-Capital Region has 12.
On average, there are now four average-speed cameras in each of Flanders’ 285 municipalities. However, Mr Quintin has not confirmed whether all 1,233 cameras in Flanders are currently operational.

The road traffic safety expert Professor Johan De Mol of Ghent University (UGent) told the press agency Belga that average speed camera systems are “valuable tools for road safety”. However, this is only the case if they are installed correctly.
“Too many are positioned just after a speed limit drops, for example from 70 to 50km/h. That’s a trap for drivers”, Professor De Mol said.

The debate concerning average-speed cameras is not new. Earlier this year, Flemish Transport Minister Annick De Ridder (nationalist) cancelled the installation of 70 new camera systems. This prompted criticism from researchers that said the number of serious accidents had fallen by 56% where average-speed camera systems had been put in place.

Meanwhile, opposition parties have also accused the government of using motorists as “cash cows”. Nevertheless, experts stress that properly designed and fairly deployed cameras are crucial for road safety.

title: Mars to close its rice packaging factory at Olen in Antwerp Province
first_lines: Mars Belgium has announced plans to close its factory in Olen. The company announced the closure in a press statement released earlier on Wednesday. Around 80 jobs are under threat as a result of the closure announcement. Mars Belgium says that economic challenges including falling production volumes and rising costs are forcing it to close the factory.
content: Mars Belgium says that the factors listed above have resulted in its Olen site being underutilised which in turn has had a significant impact on efficiency. The factory is due to close at the end of next year.
The Olen factory has been open for around 50 years and was formally part of Master Foods. It produces and packages rice sold under the Ben’s Original brand that was previously called ‘Uncle Ben’s’.

Mars Belgium said in its press statement that it had informed employees and their trade union representatives of its intentions.  The company stresses that its priority now is to engage in a “meaningful and transparent information and consultation process” and to “support employees throughout this period with care and respect.”
If the closure goes ahead Mars, will outsource the production of Ben’s Original dry rice products for the European market.

title: Belgium “at risk” from migration pressure says European Commission
first_lines: The European Commission’s 2025 European Annual Asylum and Migration Report has classified Belgium as a “risk country” with regard migration pressure.  11 other EU countries, including Germany, France, Ireland, the Netherlands and Poland are also considered by the Commission to considered to face a potential migration pressure risk.
content: The report covers the period from July 2024 to June 2025. It notes a “steady improvement” in migration trends, including a 35% fall in illegal border crossings. However, it also highlights ongoing challenges such as arrival of undocumented migrants and the reception of refugees from Ukraine.

The 27 EU member states were ranked according to factors such as the number of migrants and asylum applications, GDP and population size. Belgium is among twelve EU member states identified as facing a potential risk of migration pressure, whereby reception systems are strained or migration has been or is being used as a political tool. The latter has been seen previously in Poland.
“At risk” countries may qualify for financial support through the EU’s “toolbox” that was set up as part of the Migration Pact. The Migration Pact will take effect in June.

Meanwhile, countries, such as Cyprius, Greece, Italy and Spain that are experiencing the highest levels of migration pressure will be able to rely on help through the EU’s solidarity mechanism, whereby other member states take in some of their asylum seekers.

However, several northern countries, including the Netherlands, Belgium, Germany, Sweden and Finland, have said that they will only agree to a relocation system once the EU’s Dublin Regulation on migration is more strictly applied.

title: Moscow warns that "Belgium risks liability if frozen Russian assets are used”
first_lines: Russia has warned Belgium against seizing frozen Russian assets held by Euroclear in Brussels. The European Commission wants to use the frozen Russian cash for a new loan to Ukraine. Only once the war is over, sanctions are lifted and Russia pays Ukraine compensation for the damage inflected by the war would Ukraine repay the loan to the EU.
content: Belgium has so far been reluctant to release the money. The Belgian Prime Minister Bart De Wever (Flemish nationalist) says that he wants firmer guarantees from the rest of the European Union that the potential legal risks will be shared.

Now Moscow is has issued a warning to Belgium not to seize the money. “Belgium will face a serious liability issue if Russian assets are seized”, the Russian Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) told the Russian state press agency Tass.

“EU countries are teetering on the brink of social and economic crisis and their coffers are empty. They now want to pay for Ukrainian grain with stolen Russian assets”, SVR says. “Belgium that manages the 'joint fund', is resisting the plan because it fears it will be held liable. That is the right way to think, because they will certainly be held liable.’”

title: 17-year-olds invited to do voluntary military service
first_lines: From today (Wednesday 12 November) all 17-year-olds in Belgium will receive a letter calling on them to sign up for a year’s voluntary military service in the Belgian armed forces. The Flemish Youth Council is critical of the tone of the letter and says that if a job advertisement  placed on the Flemish Employment Service’s (VDAB) website was written in the same style, there wouldn’t be many applicants for the job. Nevertheless, the Belgian military hopes that a least 1,500 young people will sign up.
content: “Congratulations! Next year you will turn 18. This is an important milestone and a time when you will make choices for your future. The Ministry of Defence is offering you a unique opportunity, a voluntary Military Service Year”

This is how the letter that was sent to around 130,000 17-year-olds in Belgium at the end of last week begins. The aim of the letter is to encourage them to sign up for a year with the armed services. In return they will be given a salary of at 2,000 euro/month, luncheon vouchers, their medical costs will be refunded and they will be able to travel free of charge on public transport to and from work.

After an intensive 10-week basic training course, followed by a specific training course lasting 1 to 3 weeks (depending on the position), they will start work at a military barracks, where they will “take part in exercises and operations”.

The Defence Ministry says that the military service year "is a unique opportunity to develop both personally and professionally, make friends for life and gain work experience”. What's more, “you will be actively contributing to the future of our country, in an international context in which we must be prepared and ready to act."

Anna Roos of the Flemish Youth Council believes that the latter will certainly appeal to young people. She is the chair of the Flemish Youth Council and has noticed how young people are concerned about military conflicts around the world. “Sudan, Ukraine, Gaza. Every day, social media shows horrific images of war. You can't ignore it. The current issue of drones is also a cause for concern”, she told VRT Radio 1’s morning news and current affairs programme ‘De Ochtend’.

“In the past, defence was a niche issue. But now it has such an important impact on so many people in the world and perhaps soon also on our own security as well. We see defence as a form of collectieve insurance.”

Nevertheless, Ms Roos is not really certain that the letter will encourage youngsters to join up. “Although experts on young people were consulted, the letter is rather dryly worded. It does not contain much information. If this had been a vacancy on the VDAB website, not many people would have applied. A year of your life is a long time, especially when you are 18”.

Those that are interested will be given more information during info sessions that will take place between 22 November and 7 December. Attendance at once of the sessions is compulsory for anyone that wishes to do the military service. "There is only session per province, while 149,000 letters have been send. I am curious about the practicalities of this."

Anna Roos understands why the Ministry of Defence is focusing on 17-year-olds. “I am 21 and a student, so a year of military service is no longer an option for me. Many 18 to 26-year-olds have already made important choices in their lives. I think becoming a reservist is more appealing to us.”

The Ministry of Defence expects around 1,500 young people to apply to do a military service year. Of these, 500 will ultimately be able to start, this represents 0.38% of all the young people that hab been received a letter. 375 will do their military service in the army, 75 in the air force and 50 in the navy.

title: Brooch seized from Napoleon at Waterloo auctioned for €3.7 million
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: A diamond-encrusted brooch belonging to French emperor Napoleon, which was captured by the Prussian army at Waterloo (Walloon Brabant – Belgium), has been auctioned in Geneva (Switzerland) for a record €3.79 million, according to auction house Sotheby's. The auctioneers had initially estimated the sale price at between €130,000 and €220,000.
content: The brooch was among the personal belongings that the emperor had to leave behind during his flight from Waterloo, outside Brussels, when he attempted to escape from British and Prussian soldiers. It was this famous battle that ultimately sealed his downfall.

The round piece of jewellery, with a diameter of approximately 45 mm, includes a large oval diamond weighing 13.04 carats in the centre. This central diamond is surrounded by almost 100 other diamonds in various shapes and sizes, arranged in two concentric rows.

This unique piece was made for Napoleon around 1810, ‘probably to adorn his bicorne hat on special occasions,’ the auction house notes. The jewel was then presented, along with other items, to the Prussian King Frederick William III on 21 June 1815, just three days after the Battle of Waterloo, as a war trophy.

title: Education minister Demir promises shake-up of disciplinary procedures at Flemish universities and colleges: ‘Professors are not above the law’
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: Flemish education minister Zuhal Demir (Flemish nationalist N-VA) says the latest report from VRT current affairs flagship Pano on disciplinary procedures at Flemish universities shows that educational institutions are unable to deal with the problem of inappropriate behaviour themselves. Demir is having the disciplinary procedures at all universities and colleges reviewed and adjustments will be made where necessary. Like the experts, she is advocating the establishment of an independent disciplinary body.
content: Three years after Pano revealed that several universities were not taking sufficient action against inappropriate behaviour by professors. A new Pano report suggests that not much has changed since then.

Several universities have tightened up their procedures, but that is not enough for Demir. ‘Professors are not above the law,’ she told VRT Radio. ‘The days when everything was dealt with internally are over.’
Demir is also having the disciplinary procedures at all Flemish universities reviewed as soon as possible – ‘that must happen in the next six months’ – and adjustments will be made where necessary.

Since 2022, reporting channels and complaints procedures have been improved, but the new Pano report shows that internal disciplinary procedures rarely lead to severe penalties. Experts are calling for an external disciplinary body to be set up so that tougher action can be taken against toxic behaviour. This is an option that Demir is certainly not ruling out.

‘In the private sector, you would be dismissed for compelling reasons,’ the minister responds when confronted with the examples cited in the report. After an internal investigation, a professor at Ghent University who allegedly committed fraud to the tune of at least 100,000 euros was only given a financial penalty. ‘Such a punishment raises questions. We all feel that this is not acceptable.’

According to Demir, an independent disciplinary body would also be able to deal with reports more quickly. ‘Why does a procedure always have to take years?’ she wonders. ‘Investigations are deliberately being bogged down in the hope that those who reported the incident will forget about it.’

title: Bruges police use speed test bench to check mopeds and e-scooters
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: Bruges police have had a busy night. During a major check on two-wheel traffic half of all drivers checked, were found to be in violation in some way or other. People on mopeds and bikes were either speeding, had no lights or were ignoring traffic signs. One moped was even able to do 116 kilometres per hour on a test bench.
content: ‘The checks were focused on mopeds, fat bikes, e-scooters, speed pedelecs and regular bicycles. But motorists who committed offences were also pulled over,’ explains Lien Depoorter of the Bruges police.

‘We checked 156 drivers. Half of them were fine and received a gadget from our prevention team. The other half were caught committing all kinds of offences, connected to lighting, position on the road, ignoring traffic signs or traffic lights.’

The police were also on the lookout for souped-up mopeds. In Bruges they used a new test bench for the first time. It allows the speed of different types of vehicles to be measured, including fat bikes and e-scooters. ‘One moped reached a speed of 116 kilometres per hour on the test bench. That moped was confiscated and also declared forfeited. This means that the owner will never get their moped back,’ explains Depoorter.

"A total of 15 souped-up mopeds were confiscated, 12 people were fined for ignoring traffic signs, 11 for using a smartphone while cycling or riding a scooter, and 48 for not having bicycle lights. Cyclists not holding their handlebars were also fined. 23 motorists were fined for overtaking a cyclist in a bicycle zone. The Bruges bicycle zone was expanded significantly last 1 October.

‘We have noticed that many people are still breaking the rules, despite intensive prevention campaigns. Such large-scale checks remain necessary, in addition to daily detection efforts,’ concludes Depoorter.

title: Federal police stage 24-hour clamp-down on speeding across the nation
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: Belgian federal police are once again organising a 24-hour clamp-down on speeding motorists. The drive started at 6 a.m. this morning. Many local police forces are also joining in and will be carrying out more speed checks than usual throughout the day.
content: For 24 hours, a greater focus on speed in traffic is in place. Not only will officers carry out more extensive checks, but fixed speed cameras and average speed checks are also operating at capacity.

The aim of the campaign is to encourage drivers to stick to the speed limits and not to drive too fast. Many drivers underestimate the risks of speeding, which is one of the main causes of road accidents.

The speed enforcement campaign is organised twice a year, in spring and autumn. During the last edition in April, a record number of vehicles were checked: 1.339 million vehicles in only 24 hours. Almost 4 per cent of the vehicles checked were speeding. 1.69 per cent were caught by a fixed camera, while mobile speed cameras detected more than 8 per cent of offences.

The results prove that speeding is still ingrained in the driving behaviour of the people of Belgium. According to the federal police, it is absolutely necessary to continue monitoring and raising awareness. Road safety remains a priority for Belgium’s integrated police force.

title: Only 1 in 10 foreign parking fines in Brussels ever paid
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: Barely 1 in 10 parking fines handed out in Brussels to foreign motorists ever gets paid. The value of unpaid fines over the past two years now amounts to more than €25 million.
content: The figure comes from outgoing Brussels mobility minister Elke Van den Brandt (Flemish ecologist/Groen) in response to a parliamentary question from Fouad Ahidar (minority interest party TFA). The region is now investigating whether it can use wheel clamps to force non-payers to cough up.
Figures from Van den Brandt show that the collection rate among foreign drivers in 2023 was only 9.74 per cent and in 2024 it was even lower, at 9.07 per cent.
In contrast, Belgian drivers are much better at paying their fines. For vehicles with Belgian number plates, the collection rate was 80 per cent in 2023 and 76 per cent in 2024.

Van den Brandt acknowledges the problem and therefore wants to strengthen collection mechanisms for foreign drivers. Belgium currently only has bilateral agreements with France and the Netherlands for the collection of traffic fines.

‘Agreements with other countries are necessary. However, the Brussels-Capital Region does not have the authority to negotiate bilateral agreements with other countries,’ the minister said. She has now asked the federal government to conclude similar agreements with other countries.

In the meantime, additional measures are being prepared in Brussels. Parking agency Parking.brussels has plans to work together with a company that specialises in the collection of European traffic fines.
The agency will soon be given the power to immobilise vehicles with a wheel clamp or have them towed away in the event of repeated non-payment.

title: ‘Belgium appears to be the focus of increased hybrid threats’ says defence chief
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: Belgium appears to be the focus of increased hybrid threats Belgian Chief of Defence Frederik Vansina told the chamber of representatives, the lower house of the Belgian parliament on Wednesday. He was referring to recent incidents involving drones flying over airports and military bases, as well as cyber threats, ships off our coast and ‘assertive rhetoric’ on social media.
content: The defence chief had been invited to parliament for an exchange of views on the Strategic Vision for Defence 2025, which is essentially the government's long-term vision for the army and all the investments that go with it.

‘I am convinced that this strategic vision will further strengthen the ongoing reconstruction of our defence capability,’ General Vansina said. He believes that this reconstruction has been under way since 2016 and was successfully continued by the previous government.

During much of his presentation, Vansina outlined the threat facing Belgium and the world, strongly focusing on the situation in Ukraine. That war has exposed a new technological reality: the increase in drones on the battlefield.

By 2025, Ukraine will have used no fewer than 4 million drones on the battlefield, according to Vansina. ‘We haven't seen the end of it yet,’ he warned. Vansina cited drones that will increasingly be controlled by artificial intelligence – a trend that we in Europe are very wary of for ethical reasons, he explained.
Drones have caused quite a stir in Belgium in recent weeks. ‘At the moment, Belgium seems to be the focus of an increased hybrid threat,’ the general said.

This is not only true for Belgium, but is visible throughout Europe. ‘We are also seeing actions, with strong indications that they are being directed by Russia,’ he continued, pointing to the sabotage of undersea cables, cyber attacks, disinformation, and so on.

As far as the fight against drones is concerned, Vansina refuted the claim that the defence ministry had neglected the problem. The plan put forward by defence minister Theo Francken (Flemish nationalist N-VA) to counter drones is part of a comprehensive package.

It will now take a few months – ‘not years’ – to become operational. However, the lessons learned from Ukraine also show that it is important to have the latest technology in both drone and counter-drone capacity.
Assistance from our neighbouring countries, the UK, Germany and France, in the fight against the drone threat was ‘very welcome’, the general noted, but he was unwilling to comment further.
Vansina also stressed that Russia has completely switched to a war economy, with tanks, guns and ships rolling off the production line on a daily basis.
‘The question is what will happen if there is a ceasefire in Ukraine tomorrow.’ Meanwhile, China is not standing still either and is developing its armed forces and arsenal at an enormous speed.
Vansina expressed concern about this and asked politicians to consider the way in which purchases are made in Belgium.
‘We work using peacetime procedures, with all kinds of intermediate steps and rules, which slow down the procurement process, while our opponents move much faster,’ he noted.
‘I don't know if we in the West can continue using our peacetime rules. Perhaps we should sit down with the finance inspectorate and others to consider how we can speed up procedures.’

title: Driver convicted after driving with steering wheel between his legs
author: Colin Clapson
first_lines: A motorist typing on his mobile phone using both hands while driving has been fined and banned from driving. The motorist was steering his car using his legs. ‘Irresponsible driving,’ said the judge. What is and isn't allowed behind the wheel?
content: The driver attracted the attention of the motorway police because he was swerving on the motorway and crossing an uninterrupted white line painted on the road surface. The officers had to take avoiding action in order to ensure they didn’t collide with the driver. To their surprise, they noticed that the man was steering his car with the wheel between his legs while using his mobile phone with both hands!
‘I was writing an urgent email,’ the motorist said after the officers pulled him over. He had to surrender his driving licence on the spot.  It was withheld for a 15-day period.

This week, the driver had to face a judge in Sint-Niklaas (East Flanders). ‘I wouldn't even know how to drive a car with my legs. What I do know is that this is irresponsible driving,’ the judge told the defendant. The magistrate sentenced him to a 15-day driving ban and a 400-euro fine.
Operating a screen, eating or drinking while driving, lighting a cigarette, applying make-up, holding your dog on your lap... None of these activities are permitted if they could distract you!
